item.title: Event Driven Web
item.description: I’ve recently been working on a project that uses WebSockets as a core mechanic. These are my thoughts… For starters, an event-driven architecture all the way from Server to UI brings some interesting features.

item.title: Deconstruct 2017 - Stronger Communities
item.description: Deconstruct 2017 is over, and I’m still processing a lot of what I heard, but I did want to get a few notes down while the ideas are fresh. It came up a few times that the software community needs to do better in terms of inclusivity and overcoming the biases that have accumulated.

item.title: Converting Atmospheric COâ‚‚
item.description: I had an idea as I was driving today. It seems so obvious that I’m sure it has some fundamental flaw. Either that, or someone is already working on it.

item.title: Advent of Code
item.description: I’ve really been enjoying working my way through the code challenges at http://adventofcode.com/. My solutions are here: https://github.com/andyvanee/adventofcode I’m now on day 8, and the examples have ranged from very easy to pretty involved, but none have been devilishly complicated or tricky.

item.title: Multiple Foreign Keys
item.description: I’d like to document a problem that I’ve never had before, and the solution I arrived at. It was not a real complicated problem, but I got hung up on an even simpler problem.

item.title: The Case Against Frameworks
item.description: This may come across as a rant, but I’m hoping I can keep this as objective as possible: I don’t like frameworks. I’m going to use a broad definition of frameworks defined like this:

item.title: Sandbox your external scripts
item.description: Fonts and external scripts can be a real performance killer for modern websites. This is the white-screen of death for front-end web development. Anytime a page is blocked for 0.5 or more seconds due to scripts and hosts outside of your control is a serious problem in my opinion.

item.title: Re-evaluating Online Universities
item.description: Here’s an article I read a couple days ago about the founder of Udacity and his struggle with very low success rates for online courses. http://www.fastcompany.com/3021473/udacity-sebastian-thrun-uphill-climb To compensate for a high dropout rate, Udacity has made a shift to focusing on corporate training.

item.title: Accidental CMS
item.description: When I started reading this article called CMS Trap, I had no idea what the hell he was talking about. As I pushed through, I began saying ‘yes’ more and more, and by the time I was finished I had to go back and re-read it again because so much rang true.

item.title: The World is Immutable
item.description: Interesting slide deck here called Clojure: The JFDI language I haven’t done any Clojure programming, but I have done some lisp (sbcl) and Haskell, so this off-the-cuff remark caught my attention:

item.title: Udacity CS-212
item.description: Peter Norvig is a big name in computer programming. I stumbled across some of his code and was struck by how he could often accomplish in 4 lines of code things that might take me pages.

item.title: Playing With OpenResty
item.description: OpenResty is a bit of an enigma. I first heard about the project a few months back when reading about some benchmarks of various web application platforms. OpenResty was WAY ahead of all the others.

item.title: Taking Stock
item.description: As I’ve given this blog a little refresh, it’s caused me to look back on what I’ve written so far and think about what I want to write in the future.

item.title: New Layout
item.description: This blog is now compiled with Middleman and deployed with Wercker (still deploying to S3). I’ve updated the look/feel as well, mostly taking stuff away to make it really clean & simple.

item.title: Event Driven Programming
item.description: I haven’t been doing a lot of JavaScript lately, but every time I do i try to explore the idea of doing everything event driven. “I want the world to be made of hooks” -Andrew Plotkin

item.title: Spamming the Internet
item.description: When Google announced that Reader was to be no more, I, like many other geeks took things into my own hands. I was, until recently, a daily user of Reader. There are only a handful of RSS feeds that I follow, but I like them for the very fact that they are not Rich content or an Immersive Experience.

item.title: Writing Is Hard
item.description: …for a number of reasons. One reason, which is often addressed, is the challenge of effectively communicating your ideas. This is partly technical, but has more to do with how effectively you communicate in any manner.

item.title: Prose, Github and S3
item.description: In an effort to make the static site workflow a little less manual, I’ve created a little web-service to automate things a bit. Here’s how it works: Edit posts/pages/layouts etc with prose.

item.title: The Software Developers Home Lab
item.description: This post caught my eye: Why you need a home lab to keep your job. Your boss won't pay for training, so your partner has to put up with servers at home What intrigued me, as a web developer, was not setting up servers with the latest and greatest hardware.

item.title: Haskell Influenced Coffee
item.description: I’ve been learning Haskell. It’s been a very interesting experience to learn to think in the Haskell way, but I have been unsure whether it will actually have any practical benefit in my day to day work.

item.title: Global Virtual Collaboration
item.description: I have a feeling that the current age could be described as the dawn of the open-source model. It’s not just software that can benefit from a workflow that is distributed, versioned and collaborative.

item.title: Declarative Data
item.description: There seems to be certain mystique surrounding declarative programming and how it applies to the real world. There are not many technologies in the average web programmer toolkit that are truly declarative.

item.title: Digital Archiving
item.description: Librarians Helping Their Communities with Personal Digital Archiving

item.title: Old Projects onto Github Pages
item.description: I’ve moved my blog over to Github Pages, and it’s working out pretty well so far. I’m using Jekyll to generate it, which works awesome for a simple blog like this.

item.title: MVC-r The pattern you already use
item.description: The pattern you already use MVC has long been the defacto standard for building web and desktop applications. There are many variations on the theme, but I think the acronym is missing one component that is already an important part of any MVC application…

item.title: Copy Path to Clipboard
item.description: Finder makes it a bit difficult to get the full path to a file; like when you’re pasting it into config files or Terminal. So here’s a little script that makes it this easy: Browse in Finder, right click a file or folder and choose ‘Copy Path to Clipboard’.

item.title: Global Day of Code Retreat
item.description: This past weekend my co-worker, Jon, and I participated in the Global Day of Code Retreat, an event that focuses on two things: Test-Driven Development (TDD) and Pair Programming. Neither of which are exactly new to me, but in my day-to-day work there are only a handful of projects that use TDD, and we basically never do pair-programming.

item.title: Guru Graduate!
item.description: Well, today was my last day at Guru Digital Arts College. It’s been an amazing six months! I had a great feeling about the school from the day I walked in for a tour, and they didn’t disappoint.

item.title: Automate The Itch - Part 1
item.description: Small, single-purpose utility applications have a long lineage in computing history. They are the cornerstone of the UNIX philosophy, and are rampant on mobile platforms. They are the small building blocks in a larger task.

item.title: Hashtag Search
item.description: As a sideline to one of my bigger projects, I decided to build a little webapp that would search Twitter for a hashtag. Fairly basic, but it’s got a few interesting little features:

item.title: Automator Services
item.description: I keep discovering new uses for Automator. I’m not sure when the “Services” option became available, but it’s worth checking out. I had previously wrote a text-to-markdown action, which converted the clipboard contents from markdown to HTML.

item.title: Rapid Game Prototyping in Quartz Composer
item.description: I am a Quartz Composer junky. I love tinkering with ideas and hacking together logic gates within this kind of visual programming environment. I think this it’s the best way to teach core CS techniques that are often obscured in text-based code.

item.title: From Command-line to XCode
item.description: I’m a command-line guy at heart when it comes to programming. It seems much more organic to know what every project file is doing and how each one contributes to the whole.

item.title: Endangered Species and UX
item.description: I’ve just picked up Gene Wolfe’s collection of short stories, “Endangered Species” for a second read. I stopped after the introduction to think about it for a while. It’s that good.

item.title: Chaining in JavaScript
item.description: It’s been bugging me for a while that I didn’t understand the method behind jQuery’s function chaining. So I built the smallest functional version of it. I call it aQuery (for andy, or awesome).

item.title: Call For Web Standard
item.description: Developing native apps is a pain. Yes, you have the luxury of fixed screen dimensions and access to hardware features that may not be available elsewhere, but when you’re done, you have an app that only works on one platform.

item.title: Divide And Conquer
item.description: School has started and I’ve been very busy with projects, but haven’t had time to write. And in fact there’s not a lot to write about. Sure, I’ve been working on a lot of cool stuff, but the big picture hasn’t come into focus.

item.title: Photo Archiving
item.description: Backups and Archives are two different things. Ideally you should have a good archiving system, and your backup would be a redundant copy of that. In photography, a robust archiving system has between two and four copies of any file.

item.title: What The Internet Needs Now
item.description: I’ve been blogging a fair bit lately about metadata, archiving and dealing with the masses of information that we produce and consume today. It all comes from an idea that has been alternatively percolating and distilling in my mind.

item.title: Auto Metadata
item.description: One interesting part of the weekend photographic seminar I just got back from was the emphasis on metadata. It's important to take great photos, but it's just as important to know how you got those results.

item.title: Meota Summer Photographic Seminar
item.description: Just finishing up the weekend photographic seminar at the lake. Got some good shots and some good practice at composition, lighting and rhythm.

item.title: Chaotic Data
item.description: Data is chaotic. Our attempts to tame it are largely attempts at dehumanizing ourselves. Here’s a transcript of a piece of cardboard on my Grandfathers wall: ------------------------- | | | WALLET LIST | | ------ | | EARS | | CANE | | WATCH | | | | SWIM | | | |_________________________| Even by typing it here, I am imposing a fair bit more order than the original had.

item.title: Champions Of Order
item.description: Software Engineers assume that your data can be ordered logically. This assumption is built in to the file system. They assume that it's an easy task, but that it's best left to the user.

item.title: UNIX and the Emerging Web
item.description: After reading "The Art Of UNIX Programming" again, it's got me thinking about the nature of the technological explosion that has happened since the quaint days of mainframes and text-based consoles.

item.title: Assembly Language For Mac
item.description: I’m away from my Linux box and want to do some assembly programming. Mac installs GCC with the developer tools, but there are enough differences that I haven’t bothered to work through them until now.

item.title: RPN Calculator - v0.02
item.description: disclaimer: I copied this from my old blog. Not sure if it actually works:) My calculator code was quite easily polished up. Here’s the revised code which stacks operands properly and supports the main arithmetic operators +, -, * , /.
